description:
NTP5: Support thumbnail stacking and missing thumbnail images:
1. Show a stack of thumbnails when a window with multiple tabs is closed.
2. Show a favicon and URL in the thumbnail if the image couldn't be loaded.

Also allow thumbnails to have an empty string href (e.g. for a multiple tab thumbnail).

BUG=142669

Committed: http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=154791

messages.text: Merged with your change.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode93
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:93: this.renderThumbnailImage_(data.url);
Replace data.url with dataUrl.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode114
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:114: image.onerror = function() {
Include a comment here describing why we're listening to the onerror event.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode114
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:114: image.onerror = function() {
I think it would be nice to put the onerror handler as a different method, like, onThumbnailError_(). Is it possible to do that?

If so, I think the renderThumbnailImage_() might be unnecessary.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode119
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:119: banner.innerText = dataUrl.replace(/HTTPS?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/$/gi, '');
Why is HTTPS upper case, and www lower case? I suggest using lower cases anywhere, which I think is slightly more readable.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode119
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:119: banner.innerText = dataUrl.replace(/HTTPS?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/$/gi, '');
Replace innerText with textContent.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode119
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:119: banner.innerText = dataUrl.replace(/HTTPS?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/$/gi, '');
Also, I think the designers wanted the "banner" to show the domain, not just an URL without http://wwww. Is is possible to extract the domain only?

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js (right):

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:93: this.renderThumbnailImage_(data.url);
On 2012/08/23 00:08:08, pedrosimonetti wrote:
> Replace data.url with dataUrl.

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode114
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:114: image.onerror = function() {
On 2012/08/23 00:08:08, pedrosimonetti wrote:
> Include a comment here describing why we're listening to the onerror event.

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode114
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:114: image.onerror = function() {
On 2012/08/23 00:08:08, pedrosimonetti wrote:
> I think it would be nice to put the onerror handler as a different method, like,
> onThumbnailError_(). Is it possible to do that?
> 
> If so, I think the renderThumbnailImage_() might be unnecessary.

It's awkward, since in the error handler, 'this' refers to the image.  Nevertheless, I don't think renderThumbnailImage_() is necessary, now that RecentlyClosed has been simplified from an earlier iteration.

> anywhere, which I think is slightly more readable.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode119

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/2001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode119
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:119: banner.innerText = dataUrl.replace(/HTTPS?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/$/gi, '');
On 2012/08/23 00:08:08, pedrosimonetti wrote:
> Also, I think the designers wanted the "banner" to show the domain, not just an
> URL without http://wwww. Is is possible to extract the domain only?

By domain, you mean for http://news.google.com/newspapers, only show google?

There will be plenty of corner cases, like the above.  For now, I can also delete everything after the backslash.
Added the thumbnail stacking code - it would be good to test these in conjunction.
Pedro - my other CLs were committed, so to try out the demo, you'll just need to gclient sync then patch this in.

I think we can keep with this implementation for now, but as we discussed offline, we should investigate how to handle the stack thumbnails using as much CSS ass possible.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/6008/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/mock/debug.css
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/mock/debug.css (left):

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/mock/debug.css:35: border-radius: 2px;
Why are you removing this? Don't we need to override the ntp4 value?

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/6008/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:89: border-left: 1px solid silver;
nit: Why silver? We should use the same border color as before.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/6008/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css#newcode96
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:96: outline: 1px solid silver;
Nit: Why Silver? Also, why outline and not border?

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/6008/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/6008/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode110
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:110: image.onerror = function() {
nit: Move this function to this.onThumbnailError_(e). Instead of using this (or self), your're going to use e.target, which should be the image element. Once you have a reference to the image element, you can create and/or find any other elements you want, like topThumbnail and so on.

lgtm

I discussed with Jeremy offline and we decided to address some issues that I commented out later, in another CL, so I'll lgtm it now.

> nit: Move this function to this.onThumbnailError_(e). Instead of using this (or

> you have a reference to the image element, you can create and/or find any other

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/9004/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode115
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:115: banner.textContent = dataUrl.replace(/https?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/.*$/gi, '');
On 2012/08/23 23:36:28, Evan Stade wrote:
> we don't normally strip https (i.e. in the omnibox or the status bubble, we
> strip http but not https)
> 
> i'm also not sure what prevents the second part of this regex from matching the
> bracketed portion of https:[//www.google.com/]

Because we're fitting this in the thumbnail itself with a fairly large font, the designers as much stripping as possible.  We may need to revisit to pare down further.

The bracketed portion doesn't get matched, because the // is replaced, and then the second part of the regex gets run on the resulting string.

I was expecting you to leave querySelectorAll and then loop over its contents. I guess this is OK too but it seems likely to perform worse just because of the alternating between searching and modifying the DOM.

Most likely we'll need to revisit this implementation anyways, since I don't know how much of this design is final, or yet approved by UX.

Done.

Hey Pedro,

I cleaned up the stacking code as you suggested offline to support RTL and rely less on JS.  I also added the background-clip.  Please take another look?

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode55
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:55: for (var i = 0; i < blanks.length; ++i)
nit: for (var i = 0, length = blanks.length; i < length; ++i)

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode67
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:67: var thumbnailStack = this.querySelector('.thumbnail-stack');
Does this code handle the case when data.length == 0?

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode69
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:69: var stackSize = Math.min(data.tabs.length, MAX_STACK_SIZE);
You always use (stackSize - 1), so I'd change this line to:
var blankStackSize = Math.min(data.tabs.length, MAX_STACK_SIZE) - 1;

And then I'd use blankStackSize elsewhere.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode71
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:71: var blank = this.ownerDocument.createElement('div');
Nit: Thumbnail is a <a> element, which is an inline element. According to 3WC we are not supposed to have block elements inside inline elements. For this reason I think it is cleaner to use <span> instead of <div>.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode76
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:76: topThumbnail.style.width = 130 - (stackSize - 1) * 3 + 'px';
Make 3 a constant so it is easier to tweak the gap value?

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css (right):

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:23: position: absolute;
Why is this necessary?

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:46: background-size: 130px 81px;
Isn't the width 80px?

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:88: margin-left: 7px;
margin: 0 7px;

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css#newcode95
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:95: margin-left: auto;
margin: 0 auto;

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode53
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:53: '<div class="thumbnail-stack">' +
As we discussed offline, rename thumbnail-stack to thumbnail-wrapper or something similar. Also, remove top-thumbnail.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/16002/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode113
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:113: image.onerror = function() {
Nit: if you decide not to move this function now, put a TODO here so we don't forget to investigate this later.

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/9004/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/9004/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js#newcode115
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:115: banner.textContent = dataUrl.replace(/https?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/.*$/gi, '');
On 2012/08/24 00:33:23, jeremycho wrote:
> On 2012/08/23 23:36:28, Evan Stade wrote:
> > we don't normally strip https (i.e. in the omnibox or the status bubble, we
> > strip http but not https)
> > 
> > i'm also not sure what prevents the second part of this regex from matching
> the
> > bracketed portion of https:[//www.google.com/]
> 
> Because we're fitting this in the thumbnail itself with a fairly large font, the
> designers as much stripping as possible.  We may need to revisit to pare down
> further.

do not strip https without approval from security team. If you want to strip down for the purposes of space conservation, you should do what the status bubble does, which is to smartly remove components based on their importance. For example, https://reader.google.com/long/path/and?lots&of&args would become something like https://reader.google.com/... and then https://...google.com/... etc.

In fact I don't know why you aren't just showing the page title here, and leaving the status bubble as the place where the URL is revealed.

> 
> The bracketed portion doesn't get matched, because the // is replaced, and then
> the second part of the regex gets run on the resulting string.

which means it breaks on any link with a scheme that is not http or https

http://codereview.chromium.org/10854214/diff/13006/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css

> On 2012/08/24 01:26:24, Evan Stade wrote:
> > RTL support?
> 
> It's a bit tricky, since I'm using width (to get the ellipsis working).

why is it tricky?

html[dir=rtl] .thumbnail-banner {
  left: auto;
  right: 5px;
}

> 
> Most likely we'll need to revisit this implementation anyways, since I don't
> know how much of this design is final, or yet approved by UX.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode62
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:62: var blanks = this.querySelectorAll('.blank-thumbnail');
nit: I think we should get rid of the blank-thumbnail class. The blank thumbnail is a thumbnail-card that is not a thumbnail-image. So, you could replace the selector with:

querySelectorAll('.thumbnail-card:not(.thumbnail-image)')

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode80
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:80: blank.className = 'blank-thumbnail thumbnail-card';
nit: remove the blank-thumbnail class.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js#newcode84
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/recently_closed_page.js:84: thumbnailImage.style.width = 130 - blanksCount * STACK_OFFSET + 'px';
The width won't be 130 if the config.cellWidth is set to another value. Tile has no access to config other than during the initialization. Add a TODO here to fix this problem. We have two options: saving the config object into the Tile, or move the formatThumbnail method to TilePage.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css
File chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css#newcode28
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:28: .thumbnail-page .tile-cell .thumbnail-card:hover {
.thumbnail-page .tile-cell .thumbnail-card:hover

should be:

.thumbnail-page .tile-cell .tile:hover .thumbnail-card

This way, even when you mouse hover the small blank card gap, all borders from all cards will be highlighted, not just the individual card hovered. This is the expected behavior the entire stack is treated as one entity. You cannot restore just one particular tab from a session (multiple tabs closed).

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/10854214/diff/19001/chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css#newcode97
chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.css:97: .thumbnail-card:first-child {
nit: move this rule after thumbnail-card since this is more specific.

chrome/browser/resources/ntp_search/thumbnail_page.js:115: banner.textContent = dataUrl.replace(/https?:\/\/(www\.)?|\/.*$/gi, '');
On 2012/08/28 00:36:17, Evan Stade wrote:
> On 2012/08/24 00:33:23, jeremycho wrote:
> > On 2012/08/23 23:36:28, Evan Stade wrote:
> > > we don't normally strip https (i.e. in the omnibox or the status bubble, we
> > > strip http but not https)
> > > 
> > > i'm also not sure what prevents the second part of this regex from matching
> > the
> > > bracketed portion of https:[//www.google.com/]
> > 
> > Because we're fitting this in the thumbnail itself with a fairly large font,
> the
> > designers as much stripping as possible.  We may need to revisit to pare down
> > further.
> 
> do not strip https without approval from security team. If you want to strip
> down for the purposes of space conservation, you should do what the status
> bubble does, which is to smartly remove components based on their importance.
> For example, https://reader.google.com/long/path/and?lots&of&args would become
> something like https://reader.google.com/... and then https://...google.com/...
> etc.
> 
> In fact I don't know why you aren't just showing the page title here, and
> leaving the status bubble as the place where the URL is revealed.

We already show the title below the thumbnail on hover.  Reverted this to simply stripping http://www and trailing backslash for the dogfood, and will consult with UX/security on how to proceed.

> 
> > 
> > The bracketed portion doesn't get matched, because the // is replaced, and
> then
> > the second part of the regex gets run on the resulting string.
> 
> which means it breaks on any link with a scheme that is not http or https
